reviewText:
Rebirth is just as addicting as its predecessor, if not more so. I'll keep this review short and sweet, so here are the pros/cons:

Pros:
- New bosses!
- New items!
- New challenges!
- 4 New Characters!
- Save files!
- Seeds!
- Graphics are gorgeous!
- Animations are smooth and streamlined!
- Game runs better as a whole!
- Baller as hell music! (I especially love the new Mom boss fight track, it really gets your blood racing!)

Cons:
- Fullscreen is a little weirdly zoomed
- I miss the original BOI Soundtrack, as much as I love the new one
- I've heard from friends that if you're running Steam Beta it crashes whenever you take a screenshot, I'm not sure if this has been fixed already or not, but I'll say it anyway.

If you loved BOI and have gotten bored with/completed the original, then you will LOVE Rebirth.
What are you waiting for? It's time to return to the basement...

reviewText: I cannot recommend this game enough. $15 is a steal when you consider the amount of playtime you will get out of it. It is easily in my top 10 games of all time. The Binding of Isaac Rebirth is essentially a reboot of Isaac Classic, a rogue 2D action RPG shooter, with new enemies, bosses, items, item synergies, floors, and rooms. I've always found that this game expertly balances punishment and reward, as the items you get and the floors you must fight through are randomly generated. Playing skillfully and weighing your options on a floor (i.e. whether to expend bombs or keys to possibly get items) are also crucial, allowing you to control your fate in BoI to some degree. You will have runs that are nearly impossible to beat. You will have runs that will be over on the 2nd floor because of some ridiculously overpowered item/item synergy. You will have runs where you are BARELY powerful enough to beat the game, in which you can pat yourself on the back for playing tactically. Through a mixture of success and failure you will find a drive to continue playing. Games that evoke such a drive are few and far between.\n\n9.5/10

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a top-down roguelike twin-stick shooter, and one of the best games in the genre. This game takes the mechanics of the first one and improves them in literally every way, and it adds a lot of new things on top of that as well. The total item count is probably the double of that of the original, and a lot of the original items synergize in ways they didn't before. It can literally offer endless replay value if you want it to, because every run is different.

At first I was skeptical about the pixelated visual style, but that really grew on me. It also runs at a smoother framerate and it can do a lot more things because of the new engine. The music is great too.

There are just so many possible item combinations, so much content to explore and so much fun to be had. It can be extremely satisfying in one run because you have amazing items, and the next run will just completely ♥♥♥♥ on you and literally give you ♥♥♥♥. This is what makes me come back and play over and over again, because you never know what you might get.

But, seriously, ♥♥♥♥ The Lost.

A lot of the monsters are disgusting, which adds more feeling to the game, and I simply love shooting tears at enemies and seeing them explode in blood and meat.\nI enjoy playing The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth and would recommend it to a friend.

reviewText:
English
------------
Deutsch

Review for Binding of Isaac Rebirth and Afterbirth

First some things I learned after playing TBOI:
Eat every unknown pill you can find, cancer and proptosis are great, don't touch dead cats, you can't cry without eyes, bean farts can kill enemies, digging in poop can make you rich, fruit cake is bad and you cannot decide which enemie/boss you hate most. My most hated pair is Lump/Peep+The Bloat.

The Binding of Isaac Rebirth/Afterbirth is an improvement on the original TBOI in every possible way, so it's absolutely not comparable to an expansion or mod. You can chose between different characters and have to lead him through the basement, cellar and many other floors while finding different helpful (or painful) items and killing a bunch of different enemies in every room. At the end of every stage you fight a boss and proceed to the next stage after collecting your reward. That's it. Easy to learn, hard to handle. Kind of a poop simulator. Endlessly replayable, every run is different and it never feels repetitive.

++ pixel graphics (filter available for haters)
++ save function implemented (finally!)
++ new playable/unlockable characters
++ different rooms
++ hardmode
++ new enemies/bosses
++ over 400 collectibles, different hearts, chests, pills etc
++ seeds for special/different runs
++ better controls
++ more challenges
++ new areas and a new game mode
++ local coop
++ different endings

-- Curse of the blind (I really hate it)

Some last words: The proof that Cave Johnson was always right: When life gives you lemons

reviewText: I cannot recommend this game enough. $15 is a steal when you consider the amount of playtime you will get out of it. It is easily in my top 10 games of all time. The Binding of Isaac Rebirth is essentially a reboot of Isaac Classic, a rogue 2D action RPG shooter, with new enemies, bosses, items, item synergies, floors, and rooms. I've always found that this game expertly balances punishment and reward, as the items you get and the floors you must fight through are randomly generated. Playing skillfully and weighing your options on a floor (i.e. whether to expend bombs or keys to possibly get items) are also crucial, allowing you to control your fate in BoI to some degree. You will have runs that are nearly impossible to beat. You will have runs that will be over on the 2nd floor because of some ridiculously overpowered item/item synergy. You will have runs where you are BARELY powerful enough to beat the game, in which you can pat yourself on the back for playing tactically. Through a mixture of success and failure you will find a drive to continue playing. Games that evoke such a drive are few and far between.\n\n9.5/10

reviewText:
My first experiences with The binding of Isaac Rebirth

The first thing I see is a naked boy standing in a empty room, he is crying. I quickly realized that the naked boy was the I should main character, I thought to myself: I shold've watched the intro to understand what's going on. I quickly ignored my little mistake because I saw a door made out of gold. My instinks told me that i should go and see whats in there. Inside the room was a pedestal, on that pedestal is a drop of p*ss. I thought to myself: Wow this has to be some valuable p*ss. I walked over to the drop and picked it up. My character stopped crying, he was smiling. I walked back into the empty room that i came from and saw three more doors, two of the doors looked regular but one of the doors had teeth. My instinkts told me to not go in there. I explored some more and found various rooms with different kinds of enemies inside. I killed all of them using my p*ss. After alot of merciless killing and destroying countless amounts of poop i saw another kind of door. This one had a skull over it and a red light could be seen. It seemed as i had no other choice than to go in there. A quick screen of me laying on the ground crying and a big living piece of poop called Dingle next to me. I was now battling the living piece of poop. It killed me.

10/10 F*ck dingle

reviewText:
Once there was a man named Larry. And Larry did not like his basment. But one cold and stormy night; Larry, the resonable and brave man that he is proseded to wandered into his basment because he was cold. But his basment was even more cold than the rest of his house. So he ventured down deeper because he wanted to get warm, but Larry does not know what resides in his basment. When Larry stumbled across a hole in the ground he desided to inspect it. He found a spoon, a single cracker and a rock. Larry then starts to beat his body viciously with the spoon, while only made of wood the spoon splinters off into pieces. Larry continues to now impale himself with the splintres of spoon handle. Then he takes the cracker.. It was yummy. He looks down at the rock, fingers trembling, blood gushing down his finger tips. The rock crashes into Larrys skull. He becomes disorientated and stumbles into a wall. Time passes by, Larry slips in and out of consiousness, eyes filled with tears and blood, he manages to open them.  Mangled in a musty corner was his old cat.. Darrel. The time Larry has spent in his basment distorted his idea of time. Has he really been here this long, or was his time spent in the cellar been his only knowledge of his exsistance. Larry pondered the very meaning of everything. He crawls over to Darrel, tail ripped off, guts lay sprawled across the maggot infested dirt. But Larry is not filled with fear. Oh no. He proseeds to pick up his tail.. And shove it up his ♥♥♥. Larry knew this is what Darrel whould have wanted.

Larry managed to get through two rooms before he bled out.

9/10

reviewText: We all played the original Binding of Isaac, no questions asked. End of story. How could you possibly make it better? With improving everything it had. And that is what Rebirth did. It isn't just a remake, it also has quite a few things added, almost like an expansion. It added a whole bunch of items, some useful and some little less (I'm looking at you, Breath of Life...), more bosses, more rooms, better graphics, better sounds, better gameplay and BETTER POOP! There is one section the Original did better than Rebirth: music. Don't get me wrong, Rebirth's music is great and all, but Danny Baranowski's music was a masterpiece IN a masterpiece. Thankfully there is a mod, which replaces the new music with the old ones. This game is a masterpiece, so was the original. Did I already mention the better poop in the game?

reviewText:
A decent game. Didn't play very much of the original so can't say much for comparisons, but the higher framerate and more pixelized style are welcome additions.

+ Rogue-like (rogue-lite?) style with long term progression: Randomized dungeons and items every time, but you can unlock new items that will appear in later runs. Think Rogue Legacy, kind of.
+ A lot to do: Unlock new items, beat challenges, reach deeper into the dungeons and do it all with different characters.

- Snowball runs: Very often, a run will either suck or be The Greatest Run Ever. Getting good or overpowered items are vital, which brings us to...
- Items are everything / Low counterplay: At times, the game throws out punishment, not for you doing badly, but just because. For example, subterranean enemies will simply unearth on you. Of course, this won't happen if you either kill it fast enough, turn invincible or fly over impassable terrain... but for that you need items, and items are random. The game can quickly turn into beat unfair enemies with unfair items". Get ready to send a lot of prayers to RNGesus.
- Wiki game: Never close the game's wiki page. You'll need it. A lot.

? Setting / Looks: Shooting down fetuses and piles of poop with tears made of pee or blood isn't exactly that great if you ask me. Maybe you like that kind of stuff. It's a taste thing i guess (yuck).

Overall
date: a fun game which can keep you entertained for a while!"

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is the tale of a young boy who locks himself in his basement, kills his mother, crawls up her uterus and cries on her heart until it explodes.

If you haven’t played or heard of the original due to either living under a rock or being incarcerated, the game goes something like this: you go through a series of dungeons, where your objective is to kill everything in that room and move on, sort of like the original Zelda game if you can dig that. Along the way, you pick up a series of items that affect your abilities in nifty ways, such as sharp things that make you cry harder, floating babies that cry at things with you, and demonic blood lasers that turn your tears into demonic blood lasers, as the name implies. The game itself follows a linear path, but to keep things fresh, each level is randomly generated, with every dungeon having a completely new layout and different items from whence last you played. There are also secrets you can only unlock by playing the game multiple times, so the replay value is pretty nuts.

As a remake, Rebirth trumps its predecessor in pretty much every way, with a new engine, silky smooth gameplay and a heaping wad of new items, rooms, characters and challenges acting as more than enough incentive for an upgrade, even if you’ve thoroughly enjoyed the original. New to the cast is a demon thing that shoots blood lasers. There are also some other guys.

I myself have put several hours into this game and recommend that you do so as well if you value fun, challenges and laser tears. If you want to kill satan, gamble your life savings and sell your soul for dead cat parts within the span of thirty minutes, Rebirth is where you wanna be, dawg.

reviewText:
ISAAAAAAAAAAAC is back!

The original was already the best indie game ever released, imo. And Rebirth just makes this legendary game even more EPIC!

First of all, I have 300+ hours of gameplay in the original. I wanted to play this game so bad, but I also had really high expectations. My first impression of the game (4 hours of gameplay) is 99% positive. I'll list some of the highlights:

Positive:
+ New graphics and lighting. TOTALLY AWESOME.
+ LOCAL CO-OP MODE!
+ Smoother gameplay, specially moving Isaac with a analog stick controller (I use a Dualshock 4).
+ Lots of new stuff: New items, new item combos, new room types, new unlockable characters, new enemies and bosses, etc.
+ Better synergy when you pick up different special items.
+ Some of the old items were reworked to become more balanced/useful.
+ Hard mode option, although I didn't try it yet.

Neutral:
- The soundtrack is really good and it's clear that those guys put a lot of work on it, but it's not as epic as the original, unfortunately.
- I thought Rebirth would have a improved menu, with more details on items you have picked and secrets you have found. You still have to figure out what the items do by testing them during your gameplay. It can be either a positive or a negative thing. Personally, I'd like to see more details on the items.

Negative:
- Although Rebirth has the co-op mode option, you can't play it online with a friend. That's a bit annoying and the only real downside of this game so far.

Summarizing, it's a HUGE improvement on the original BoI, and it's totally worth buying it if you're into rogue-like style and challenging games! And if you didn't play the original, you'll have TONS OF SECRETS to find.

Final Rating: 9.5/10

reviewText:
To start this review off I'd like to say that at the time of me writing this I have played the game for 8 hours. I believe that this has been enough time for me to asess its gameplay/features and write a review.

Pros and Cons of Rebirth
Pros:
Rebirth has plenty of items (341) that you can collect which 'synergise' very well together and create wonderful combinations
Great replay value (seriously, there's 184 in game achievements)
Two player co-op
Soundtrack is okay... kind of
Multiple save files
Lots of new Challenges (20) to complete
Quicker loading time than in the original
New bosses and regular enemies
Enemies and bosses have been re-balanced
Faster and smoother than the original Flash version
Nicer asthetics (animations and background details)
DEM SYNERGIES SO DAMN GOOD
Seeds allow you to perfect levels and practice as well as get easier runs
New 'Hard' difficulty allows Experienced players to feel more challenged
4 new characters: Azazel, Lazarus, The Lost and Eden
New Guppy like 'Lord of the Flies' transformation as well as 'Bandage Girl' for Super Meat Boy
Cons:
New pixelated graphics aren't excactly everyone's favourite form of art
Harder to get items since there're so many
New music can get annoying and repetetive
Mouse support requires going into the game files and acessing the config file from there
Too expensive unless during a sale
Seeds can be considered cheaty
Certain Synergies can be game breakingly OP
Permadeath can annoy certain people
The Lost is the most annoying character that you can play
Runs are more inconsistant and are either really OP or really UP
The 'Filter' just makes everything blury causing your vision to lose focus (at least in my case)
Poop jokes and Religous based content is REALLY obnoxious (I know Edmund's a Christian and he has certain beliefs that may be considered odd but it gets annoying when everything is either religously themed or just meme themed)
My Opinion
To me, Rebirth is a pretty good game. It's solid, playable (in both difficulty and bugs), has good replay value and kills time. Yes, I miss the old graphics. Yes, I hate that you have to go into the files to add mouse support. However, this game those what is says and says it very well. The poop jokes die quickly as well as the religous referancing but Rebirth not only adds even more content but makes me want to waste my time playing it!

Final Score
I give Binding of Isaac: Rebirth an:  8/10   Because: it's a brilliant sequel but the asthetics have been greatly impaired and runs can be inconsistently OP/UP.

Edits:
02/04/205, Edited the review to inform about mouse support, thank you ShadoWatcher!
31/12/2014, Fixed Pro comment being in the Cons section and vice versa

reviewText:
Take heed fellow gamers! The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is not for the faint of heart. This game will test many things of you!

First, your standards and tolerance of what's acceptable to see in video game graphics and story. Isaac features cartoon depictions of urine, fecal matter, drug references, blood/guts, religious commentary♥♥♥♥♥♥ences, and darker references. Not bothered by these? Proceed.

Second, this game will test your luck. Every playthrough is random provided you don't enter in a seed for it. The only thing you'll find that are the same are the floor themes you traverse and general enemies you'll find. Otherwise, floor and room layouts are randomized. You'll never know what item you'll find in a treasure room, or whether risking health or resources is worth it for an item that may or may not be there. You may get a tremendously helpful item or something that could even make your run more challenging if you don't know what it is. A big part of the game is making the most out of the cards... errr items (you still find cards) that are given to you, taking risks, and creating your own luck.

Finally, this game tests your prediction, dodging, and less so: aiming skills. Oftentimes you're placed in overwhelming situations where you must act quickly deciding on where to move to avoid attacks, or predict where an enemy might move towards you. As the game progresses you're placed in somewhat to literal bullet hell" situations where you must carefully path around projectiles clumped together. You'll eventually learn quick reactions and proper pathing to navigate around damage.

This isn't an easy game and many will find themselves frustrated with potentially bad luck or how difficult it is to remember what everything does or how to deal with certain enemies/layouts. This difficulty can be a turnoff for many. It's not brutal like a few other games
date: but it definitely ain't no Legend of Zelda.\n\nSpeaking of Legend of Zelda.... Well
recommended:
The Binding of Isaac series does take some inspiration from Zelda aesthetically and gameplay-wise. Describing gameplay of Isaac: I would say it controls like a multidirectional shooter (like Robotron 2084) with dungeons and item collection/powerups taken from The Legend of Zelda generated in a rogue-like manner.

Once you will yourself to keep pushing through the initial frustrations of dying again and again you'll find yourself addicted to bettering your playthroughs. You first make it past the first few floors. Then you finally pass one checkpoint. Then another checkpoint. You've finally beaten a complete playthrough.... but then you realize you've only completed this with the base character (Isaac) and have to do the same with the ten (twelve if you have the Afterbirth expansion) unlockable who all possess different starting stats and items.

On top of this you're given various challenges
hoursPlayed: secrets
voteText:
and achievements that unlock more content in the game that will truly test your skill whether it be going through a run handicapped (like relying on low-damage close range weapons) or traversing two floors without incurring damage.

Sooner or later you're dedicated to completing every last secret and challenge to the point you hit that praised "Platinum God" status. Then what's left? Self-imposed challenges! I personally like seeing how high of a win streak I can attain with the game's random character: Eden; whom starts every run with random stats and two starting items. As expected you're tasked to deal with what you've started with and see if you can win even with a bad starting item or stat.

Isaac Rebirth's nostalgic graphics are solid. While I generally frown upon indie games tugging at nostalgia using retro graphics: Rebirth does put some appreciated modern touches into the mix using dynamic lighting and filters. At first I found myself not too sure about the game's departure from the flash style seen in the previous iteration in the series
helpfulPercent: but looking back: the flash style was crude and somewhat ugly. The game's soundtrack is very fitting with a select few being memorable. It's nothing that'll win awards
votesHelpful: but some tracks do warrant adding to your MP3 player if you're into game soundtracks.\n\nSo who would I recommend this game to? A dedicated gamer who's looking for tough
votesTotal: rouge-like
votesFunny: and addictive "climb-the-latter" gameplay. Just by addictive gameplay and content alone: I've placed The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth/Afterbirth into my Top 10 favorite games."

reviewText:
Product received for free

Isaac is a FUN, incredibly sturdy, and immensely replayable addition to the emerging action Roguelite genre.

Gameplay 10/10
With a simple, polished, and intuitive gameplay format, Isaac really shows what the action genre is capable of. The controls are extremely tight, and there are very few occasions where it feels like you are not in control of how your run goes. It's also marked by a near-infinite level of replayability, as the game is tough as nails if you can't break the initial barrier but becomes extremely satisfying and enjoyable if you manage to surpass it with a combination of your skill and game dynamics.

The main thing about Isaac that really stands out is that it takes the concept of breaking a game and builds an entire system of meta-gameplay around this, with secret bosses that practically require you to break your run in fun and empowering ways and unlocks that require hundreds of instances of experimentation and recombination of gameplay elements. The game has hundreds of hours of unlocks that really test your mettle and determination, and maybe thousands of hours more of pure unadulterated fun in replayability.

Presentation 8/10
Stylish and fluid, the graphics are pretty stunning and not oversold by-the-numbers pixel-ification. There are subtle homages to pretty much the entire history of videogames, but despite being obvious to seasoned players they are presented in a very original and uncompromising way. The soundtrack and soud design is phenomenal and while not perfect really suits the game world and tone just as well as the visual feel.

Accessibility 6/10
This, I think, is Isaac's greatest downfall, and i strongly believe it comes from the format of the game. Its random nature extends the gameplay in a way that means you will often have polarisingly difficult runs, from times when you can immediately tell you will win without much hassle to endless streaks of runs where you will be made to feel like a helpless fish out of water. It is the only element of the game that feels out of the player's control, especially when you're first starting out and don't completely know the ropes. I cannot say for sure what could remedy this, because it is sure to deter some players from continuing the experience, but it is certainly not such a sordid detail that it ruins the entire gameplay experience.

Overall 8/10
I cannot emphasise this enough: It is FUN. It can be a ♥♥♥♥♥ sometimes, but if you can allow yourself not to take the experience too seriously you are guaranteed to become totally submerged in all of its quirks and subtleties that create the immensely replayable experience of Isaac.

reviewText:
I don't know where to start, I've never had as much fun playing a game as this, It's truely amazing. I'll Tell you pros, and cons about Binding of Isaac: Rebirth...

Pros
+Tons of achievements
+Tons of new bosses (even more than Wraith of the lamb DLC for the previous Binding of isaac.)
+60 FPS
+New characters to play as
+Tons of new creatures
+Tons of new items you can can collect
+A lot of new rooms/maps
+Action is better than the old one
+Sound effects are a lot better(Tears for instance)

Cons:
-Easier to beat than normal binding of Isaac (Unless hard, or fighting mom's heart.  Or fighting Satan)

There is more Cons, and more Pros, but that means this review would be to long to read :)
Binding of Isaac gives tons of hours of gameplay fun! Would strongly reccomend this for any price!

reviewText:
Ok i admit it....I have not had time to play this title as much as I have wanted to.

The original Binding of Issac was fun....a very zelda like game with lots of interesting snafus and alot of dark humor.

This game is technicaly a remake...but oh is it a remake.  They really pulled out the stops on this one.  They use a new engine for this title and improve and expand the original game in alot of unexpected ways.

Aside from alot more achievements the actual game worlds are no longer just a collection of rooms in a grid.....now some rooms can be very differing shapes...enemies have been added and some changed, game play feels more fluid...and there is alot more to find in this title.

I only cleared the game once....thus why my time as i write this is low.

For those that have played neither title here is the synopsis....there is a trailer that shows this as well and a nifty text description.

You are treated to a nice video as the game starts....about Isaac being a happy boy living with his mother.  One day his mother gets spoken to by what she thinks is god...and god tells her to do some things to prove herself to him.

Well Isaac, over hears this....and fearing for his life....escapes to the basement below his room.....and thus the fantasy adventure begins.

No game so far I have played of this title has been the same.  There are unlockable characters and alot of things to find.  Tons of achievements and for the completists you can even collect items as the game keeps track of the things you find as you play.  Whihc in turn unlocks achievements.

A friend has a twitch TV channel and tends to play this game a bit.
<Shameless plug for the channel: http://www.twitch.tv/mr_bo_jenkins>

If you are interested in an interesting but dark humor full adventure role playing game. I do recommned this title.

This game.... I really like it. It is superior to the last game in almost every way IMO, though it seems like a lot of people hate the soundtrack. (The Rebirth one, anyway. Or don't get it. That's also OK. It's not for everyone. Though most people seem to love it.

reviewText:
Rebirth is THE definitive edition of The Binding of Isaac, no questions asked. It has:
-a new highly optimized game engine (you'll consistently get 60fps)
-a fantastic new pixel-art style
-even MORE content added to the original (I have 33 hours and I've barely scratched the surface of it)
-balances to content that was in the original
It's a wonderful upgrade to an already fantastic and fun game. Yeah, the learning curve is a bit steep, but if you get into it, it's so much fun. I cannot recommend this game enough, especially for those who like rogue-likes and bullet-hells.

reviewText:
This game is absolutely fantastic. There's an insane amount of items that will make *every* playthrough different (randomized maps and rooms adds to that as well). If you liked The Binding of Isaac (and/or the Wrath of the Lamb DLC) then you will more than likely love this at least as much.

The music between this and its predecessor is quite different, where Rebirth has a much creepier feel to it. Music wise it's completely different from the first TBOI, but it is also amazing. Ridiculon really nailed the creepiness factor.

I highly recommend this game for fans of TBOI and dungeon crawlers. It's an amazing game, especially for its price.

reviewText: Ridding itself of all of Flash's issues by shifting to a new engine, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth has essentially improved on every aspect of the original tital of the series. The graphics, although distinctly different than the original have a nice feel to them and make the games atmosphere ever the more demented but delightful. Likewise the reworked lighting and sound design adds to the immersive experience that this game provides. Not only were the core components of the game amended to improve the user's playthroughs, but an immense amount of new content was added to make the game have nearly limitless replay value. Having added to the already abundant amount of items and combinations available to experiment with in the original, Rebirth creates a profound element of mystery that hard-core fans of rogue-likes and the original game could die for.\n\ntl;dr Just buy it if you enjoy rogue-likes or even if you don't. It's guarenteed to make you smile at least once.

reviewText: Bursting forth from its parent game and glistening with vile secretions in the dim light of the basement, The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth then proceeds to cannibalize that from which it grew, mutating it into a disgusting, disturbing (and possibly sacrilegious) beast that is in every way an improvement over its predecessor. Developer Nicalis has done an incredible job taking Edmund McMillen and Florian Himsl's original The Binding of Isaac and transforming it into a tighter, smoother, and all-around better experience.\n\nJust like the previous game, Rebirth is a rogue-like game that borrows heavily in gameplay style and presentation from older iterations of The Legend of Zelda, presenting players with a top-down view of each floor of an ever expanding dungeon. Player upgrades, items, enemies, and floor layout are randomized with each playthrough as the player attempts to reach the end of the game. One of the best features of Rebirth (and the original game) is that by continually playing, the game expands itself more and more: beating the game unlocks new items, characters, and levels, making the experience grow each time you complete it! It's a title that contains a considerable heft of replayability, which works well with the pick up and play" format of the game. On top of this
date: the old-school difficulty curve coupled with the knowledge that if you die you must start again at the beginning creates a very intense game once getting into the later levels.\n\nIt should be noted that I adored the original The Binding of Isaac and its DLC
recommended: managing to achieve 100% completion after 149 hours of play. However
hoursPlayed: the original had several major flaws: one of the biggest in particular being that it was Flash-based and (despite programmer Florian Himsl's best efforts) was buckling under the weight of its own content. Scores of bugs began presenting themselves as the game got more and more added to it

reviewText:
I can't stop playing this game.  It's just too much fun.

The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth takes the fantastic formula of the original and supercharges it with nearly immeasureable amounts of content.  Much like the original, Rebirth is a challenging roguelike dungeon crawler with randomly generated levels and a plethora of creative and enjoyable power-ups.  The imagery is dark and unsettling, which complements the beautifully eerie soundtrack to create a powerful atmosphere.

If you're familiar with the original and are wondering what makes Rebirth different, then there is no shortage of things to mention.  Perhaps the most important difference is the major performance improvement.  The Binding of Isaac had notable performance issues, with many unfortunate players (myself included) unable to fully enjoy the game.  Rebirth is a far more stable game with significantly smoother gameplay.  As far as content goes, Rebirth adds several new characters, as well as new enemies, levels, power-ups, achievements, and items.  It also supports local co-op for multiple players on the same PC.  There is a new level seed feature where you can input a seed" to play a specific level with the same randomized elements every time
date: which is fantastic for speedrunners or competing friends.\n\nWhile this game already has loads of replay value thanks to its randomized nature
recommended: I personally find it especially fun to replay as a completionist.  With a huge plethora of achievements
hoursPlayed: there is always more to do in this incredible game.  Highly recommended."

reviewText:
I can honestly say this is one of the best games I have ever played.

Gameplay- This is the core of the game and what makes it as good as it is. All the great parts of the original Binding of Isaac have been retained, and (as far as I know) all of the bugs removed. The game runs very smoothly on nearly any computer. The pool of upgrades/items you can obtain during a playthrough has been increased from the original as well. With over 400 items available, you certainly won't be disappointed by a lack of diverse powerups to choose from. Also, since the floors are randomly generated similarily to a dungeon crawler, you'll be able to play through the game over and over again and never have the exact same experience more than once. But what if you did want to replay a really fun playthrough again? Rebirth has you covered there as well. With the new seed system, you can just type in the 8-digit code found on your pause screen in each playthrough and tada! Now you can play through again with the same room and floor layout (Items are retained as well).

Story- Alright, to be honest, this isn't the game's strong point. But who would expect it to be? The roguelike genre is all about the gameplay, and the story takes a backseat here. While the story certainly isn't bad, in fact it is pretty funny, it just isn't the main focus of the game. If you played the original, you won't be getting any surprises here- Rebirth features the exact same story as the original, down to the cutscene that plays when you start the game for the first time. So while it really shouldn't affect your enjoyment of the overall title, if you want to play something that is very heavy in story, this is not your game.

Graphics- Those of you who played the original will notice that the graphics have been changed from the thick lined/hand drawn styled....style, to the pixel art that is present in Rebirth. At first I wasn't too happy with this, as I had really enjoyed the art style of the original. However, after over 45 hours of playtime, I can easily say that I prefer the pixel art. Those who hate pixels with every fiber of their being have the option of turning on a filter which will smooth out the lines.

Soundtrack- The soundtrack is in the same boat as the graphics. The original's soundtrack has been thrown out along with the original's graphics. many have complained about the new soundtrack, claiming that it doesn't quite live up to the one it replaced, but I personally find it difficult to decide which is better between the two. Both manage to do different things. The original was all about the atmosphere, especially in the later levels. Rebirth, however, features more guitars and sounds closer to a metal album. They both managed to fit well with the game, in my opinion, but if the soundtrack is a major point for you, I would recommend looking it up on youtube.

To sum it all up, I highly recommend this game to anybody and everybody who is able to find a way to play it.

Pros
Amazing gameplay which somehow manages to improve upon the nearly original
Detailed pixel art
Energetic soundtrack
Cons
Soundtrack isn't quite as atmospheric as original
Pixel Graphics (if you aren't a fan of them)

9.5/10

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a perfect remake of the original game. Everything from the original game is still in place, and most likely works better than what you remember. It has a great all new soundtrack, new art, and plenty of new content you could've never imagined. I own the game on every platform available to me, N3ds, Xbox 1, and Playstation vita.

With the recent addition of the expansion Afterbirth, i've decided to update my review, and sure I could write a review for afterbirth specifically, but I think this is more suitable. With or without the DLC content, the game is so worth the money.

Afterbirth is a huge addition, to an already great game. New music, game mode, unlocks, character(s), items, trinkets, consumables, secrets, and daily challenges.

Daily challenges really give the game more life. All items are unlocked for everyone in the daily challenges, so even a complete noob can get the same experience everyone else has had. Its unfortunate that people cheat on the daily run. You can't really blame the devs for this one, its all the community.

Greed mode is a new game mode that plays out in waves of enemies, and the reward being cash money. You progress through the game mode by hoarding the shop for its best items, and you will end up at ultra greed, a new boss which will likely give you a run for your money. Overall I think its a very fun game mode, but some of the unlocks require grinding out greed mode (not cool!).

I cannot recommend this game enough.

reviewerDisplayName: Day Man Champion of the Sun
reviewText:
Okay, so my first review for this game was kind of shotty and I re read and then hated myself for writing it. These are more collective thoughts on the game after I've played it a little bit more and went back to the original to look at the diffrences in the games.

Things I liked about this game

Gameplay

Overall, the gameplay was really nice. The controller support was an amazing addition and I found myself using the controler over the keyboard becuase it was much easier to control then using arrow keys. The boss battles were fun espically near the end of the game when you have a ton of items and your heart is beating out of your chest as your hp drops to one heart. Those moments are what drove me to keep playing this game. Items felt like each one had a huge impact on the game to get, nothing seemed small and a lot of them could be complete run breakers so even more so then the previous game knowing what items did was crucial. Rooms in general had such a large vairty of layout that it never really felt the same it was always a new experience. Getting hit anywere always made me cuss under my breath knowing how hard it could be to find health unless you really scavanged the areas which was one of my favorite parts of the harder difficultes.

Graphics

Overall the graphics looked really nice, the little effects that were added to this game helped imerse me into the world more then in the previous game. The 16 Bit style was done really nicley in this game and I could still tell all of the previous eniemes from the past game was. It all seemed new but not new enough to make me forget what game I was playing.

Replay-Ability

THe later levels of this game really shined. If i lost, I kept wanting to go back to it to try and get farther then I had the previous time. Random level design and room design mixed with a large amount of diffrent items that all did something diffrent from the last means that no run is every exactly the same, so it still feels fresh after around the 300th death and restart. Achivements could never be gotten in the a single run and you had to get the right circumstances a lot of the time to even get half of them which isnt a bad thing, it drove me to play it again.


Things I did not like


Gameplay

While there was a lot of diffrent things that could happen in this game as far as characters go there was a sumpreme lack of difference, the only really things that changed were stats none of the characters besdies Azel really changed how you had to play the game. We were told that Samson might be more of a melee character which would have been really cool to see but nothing was relesed on that and he just ended up being the same guy he was in the last game except with a few buffs to blood lust. I found myself playing Azel more of the time becuase it was something diffrent then the same mundane tears that you had to start off with. That actually ties into another big problem I had with this game, starting out. The first three of four levels of the game felt so slow and dragged out to me, your damage was usually very low and it took forever to bring one enemy down. It felt more like a chore to get through then actually playing. This was strengthed after having a really really good run and then seeing issac or whoever you may be playing having these little tears shoot out after experiencing knives going every which way. Other issues that I had involved that were run breakers, as I stated earlier you had to know what each item did but to a first time player seeing the cursed eye it looks really similar to another item. I know the game is supposed to be difficult but let that be in the fighting now having a single item that looks very similar to another trash an entire run.

Graphics

Even though the 16bit style has a bit of a charm to it, I feel it's a  little over played in video games today. It can look very beautiful if done correctly and it in no way dosent in this game but I really enjoyed the original style. I wish it had kept to that except gotten a big overhall in how things looked, even with all the graphical glitches and other varius issues the original game had I liked the art style so much better. It made bosses feel more challenging for me, it made mom feel more threatening. When i saw the pixaleted mom foot drop down I almost laughed a little becuase even though yes it still looked threatining the 16bit style took a large amount of the impact tha game had on me.

Replay-Ability

I'm going to restate a lot that I said in gameplay here but go into more detail. A perfect example of the bordem that I suffered in the first two levels was after about a week or so of not playing the game I decided to boot it back up and give it another shot. I picked issac and started shooting at an enemy, after realizing how slow my shots were and how long it was taking the enemy to die then seeing that happen room after room after room on the first floor I gave up on playing it. A lot of the time I had to froce myself through the first few levels becuase I knew how much I enjoyed the later levels. The only fun I really had constantly going back was with Azel becuase enimes that didnt pose any threat died way quicker then other people. Even though the rooms were randomly generated and you didnt see the same room all the time, after a while of playing that didnt seem to matter to me. The rooms seemed the same, the same colors the same the same things to kill. I really wish there was a varient in all of that, even if the same creatures had a randomly generated apperence but still stayed the same morphies flesh blob that it used to be. It would make everything seem a lot more fresh to me.

Overall
7.5/10

I would still buy it, for the cost it should give you more then enough play time before you start to notice all of the things that I pointed out.

reviewerDisplayName: You think you do, but you don't.
reviewText:
Probably unlike any game you've played before on the whole, but you'll want more like it.

What might start as aimless room to room until death.. with a goofy premise... you realize is much more complex.
Lots to do and each run feels different.
You're playing the game to unlock more items with which to play the game to unlock more items with.
Cool challenges will fit you with a certain synergy of items from the start, changing your style of play.

You might have favorite items, but certain ones will have great symbiosis and others will seem to cancel each other out.

You'll take risks with bombing walls, looking for the hidden room you NEED to possibly get a coin or two to afford that ever important single heart or item.

At every turn you're evaluating... Will this be worth it?"...
Purchasing this game you can be sure to get your coins worth.  One of the strongest roguelikes on steam.

The Bindings of Isaac Rebirth is a very intuitive multiplayer expierience. With up to 11 player local co-op. This only applies if you have ludo. Actually, this game is super fun doesn't get old and is full of amazing music.

And that is why my final rating for this game is a Ed Mcmuffin/10!

reviewText:
There’s a TL:DR summary at the bottom if you’re not bothered.There is a lot to say about this game. This game is fun, enjoyable and has loads to offer in terms of content. Let’s start what they improved from the original Binding of Isaac game.

Original VS Rebirth Improvements:
Improvements to the Mom, Isaac and ??? boss fight.
Isaac/??? Boss fights aren’t that similar anymore, I found it redundant to make them that way in the original as it’s just a reskin of them same boss and felt like an excuse just to extend gameplay
Samson fells more enjoyable to play (I never play as him in the first one and I still don’t but every time I do, it is noticeable better than the original game)
Improvement of some items that were in the original
Character transformations based of getting 3 certain items of a set (my favourite improvement of them all)
Availably of harder difficulties for people that may want them.The only petty quality about it in comparison to the first game is the soundtrack.


This game has many wondering attributes that I felt that makes the game a joyous experience.
Positives:
LOADS of items to find/unlock and play around with. I just get excited whenever I go into a treasure room and expect the huge possibilities of what might be that I feel keeps the game fresh for a long period of time.
PLENTY of great item synergies. Synergies are when you combine 2 effects of an item to make them have a unique and deadly effect. There’s just so many it keep my curiosity anticipating the ‘what if’ when I see items that could make or break my run. My favourite is Brimstone + Tiny Planet or Spoon Bender.
Huge variety of characters all with unique characteristics and stats to make them feel as if they’re not just reskins.
Hours of gameplay and discovery.
But the game isn’t perfect, I’ll list the negatives I feel that make the game take a step in the wrong direction that probably can be justified.
Negatives:
Some items feel like they exist just to hinder you.
Sometimes it feels this game doesn’t let you perform to the best of your capabilities because you weren’t lucky enough to find decent (e.g. not finding enough keys which leads to skipping 60% of treasure rooms, granted that is genuinely unlucky). However if you find the whole luck factor unenjoyable, you can fully plan a run with seeds which ‘kind of’ makes up for this negative.
Some characters despite being harder to play as rarely make up for it (I fully understand the developers intended this).
Pop up enemies can be easily frustrating. Most of the time, it feels more of a patience mind game rather than actual gameplay. It’s genuinely unfair having an enemy pop up right under your feet, instantly hurting you then getting away with it while waiting again or waiting in irritation for 3 minutes in a room full of pop-up enemies/bosses taking so long to give you a chance to kill them!
Character movements ‘could’ be better. Don’t get me wrong, the character moments are great in the game but it’s kind of gets me down whenever I’m weaving through enemy bullets or failing to use terrain as a shield when having flight because the light movement input was still a little too much and take more than 3 tries to get it right. Trust me, it’s not as bad as I make it sound.

I would rate this game 8/10.



TL:DR SummaryMay not be the best game, has a lot of ups and content. Has some minor downs but is still very enjoyable, would rate 8/10.

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a perfect remake of the original game. Everything from the original game is still in place, and most likely works better than what you remember. It has a great all new soundtrack, new art, and plenty of new content you could've never imagined. I own the game on every platform available to me, N3ds, Xbox 1, and Playstation vita.

With the recent addition of the expansion Afterbirth, i've decided to update my review, and sure I could write a review for afterbirth specifically, but I think this is more suitable. With or without the DLC content, the game is so worth the money.

Afterbirth is a huge addition, to an already great game. New music, game mode, unlocks, character(s), items, trinkets, consumables, secrets, and daily challenges.

Daily challenges really give the game more life. All items are unlocked for everyone in the daily challenges, so even a complete noob can get the same experience everyone else has had. Its unfortunate that people cheat on the daily run. You can't really blame the devs for this one, its all the community.

Greed mode is a new game mode that plays out in waves of enemies, and the reward being cash money. You progress through the game mode by hoarding the shop for its best items, and you will end up at ultra greed, a new boss which will likely give you a run for your money. Overall I think its a very fun game mode, but some of the unlocks require grinding out greed mode (not cool!).

I cannot recommend this game enough.

My advice, though, is if you're looking to get Rebirth, just go with Rebirth in the beginning. No sense in buying the DLC as well if you end up not liking it. That's like going to the store and buying kale in bulk if you've only ever had spinach and decided that they are kind of similar and I might enjoy it".

reviewText: If you like a good challenge for both you will, mind and self-esteem, this game is perfect for you. With great music, random runs and tense fights every room, it will scare you more than any next-gen game out there. I have played this game for over 50 hours, and I have not even scratched the surface of this game's full glory. With random seeds spicing up runs so you never get bored, plus the game having unique items that can ether ruin or totally carry or run, will really have you begging to mlgesus for that one extra soul heart for good measure, or good items in your shop/item rooms, or you praying that Bob's Rotten Brain does not spawn in your azazel run. But, in all and all, this game is a great game, perfect for when you are bored or on a long ride/flight.  But , heed this word of advice; A. If you have low range,  NEVER  pick up Bob's Rotten Brain, or you will suffer exploding pain. B. Try not to pick up Soy milk, it is really tricky to use. C. If you hate a run a lot, holding R will restart your run with the same character, but with a different seed. D. Unless you are sure  DO NOT PICK UP DEAD CAT   It takes away all but one red heart container, and gives you 9 lives  E. Satan and Isaac are really hard to defeat, so get into a grove before you fight them.\n\nBy the way, this game plays like Super Meat Boy, so if you don't like that game, this probably is not the game for you.

reviewText:
So I'm going to preface this by saying that, I've spent a lot more time ingame than steam says. I've spent ~3k hours on vanilla, and ~500 in this one. I mostly play offline to be free of distraction, especially when speedrunning.

So there are a few important things about this game, and the series.

The most important thing is of course, the game itself. It's a pseudo-roguelike, with some saying it is, and some saying it's not. The game is a top down, twin-stick, procedurally generate, dungeon-crawler.

But that's not important.

If you really want to know what it's about, here:

A naked child, running around, killing his own worst nightmares that have manifested into his reality. With his tears.
if you enjoy popping poop and crying a whole lot, you'll love this game. If you don't, you'l probably still love this game.

It's unique in the fact that the game has synergies that make it exciting. A significant portion of the items synergise with eachother in quite unique ways. Edmund McMillan and Nicalis have gone above and beyond the expectations for item synergy, and are even adding to that in the DLC set for October 30th!

The next big thing about the game is the community.

Isaac is a game that is streamed and recorded quite a bit.

The thing is, you can learn a lot about the game by just watching people play it. Be it some obscure mechanic that helps you in the future, or some item synergy you haven't seen before, waching others play is a great experience.

Some of the most influential figures in this regard are:

Northernlion (https://www.youtube.com/user/Northernlion): The scumlord. He throws won runs, wins thrown runs, and generally makes plays that make you both laugh and cry. that plus his amazing voice make him a friendly resource for beginners to understand how unintimidating the game can be if approached right!

Bisnap (https://www.youtube.com/user/Bisnap): He's pretty good at the game. He is probably one of the most analytical players of the game, and provides insightful commentary as well as a good explanation as to why he made some of his more confusing plays!

Cobaltstreak (http://www.twitch.tv/cobaltstreak): He is generally a very skilled, and slightly crazy player. He was one of the first, if not the first person/people to get Real Platinum God, and beat the secret character to completion. Now he streams his Eden streaks, winning more than a hundred matches in a row before finally losing one!

The other side of the community are the people who serve as figureheads for learning! Be it by modding, or making a website to help with your every Isaac need, there are people who are there for it.

http://moddingofisaac.com/
https://www.reddit.com/r/themoddingofisaac/

Those sites are two great modding resources, and if you're interested in learning, come check out the wiki on the second link!

And then there is http://platinumgod.co.uk/

Dedicated community member Elucidator (https://twitter.com/eluc_) maintains one of the best community resource sites for the game.

So basically, Isaac isn't just a game. It's a game driven by an outstanding community that has always supported itself and keeps the Isaac experience amazing.

So I guess I'm saying that you should totally buy the game.

reviewText: The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth (more commonly called Rebirth") is a rogue-like top down tear shooter inspired by Zelda and made by the god himself
date: Edmund McMillen with the help of Nicalis. The game is very similar to Zelda 1
hoursPlayed: killing enemies (with his own tears. I'll get there) and destroying bosses and going deeper and deeper into the sanity of Isaac. The game is very famous for it's controversial story
voteText: taking a stab at religious groups.\n\nIn the story
helpfulPercent: Isaac is a little boy who lives with his christian mom
votesHelpful: until the mom hears a voice from above
votesTotal: which she assumes is her God
votesFunny: and the voice asks for her to cleanse his son
commentsCount: by taking everything that is fun in his life
column16: such as his toys
column17: drawings and his clothes. The voice isn't satisfied yet
column18: so it demands a sacrifice of Isaac (much like the biblical story)
column19: but Isaac manages to escape her psycho mom by going down a trapdoor hidden on a carpet
column20: and going down to unknown depths below
column21: eventually being powerful enough to face her mom again.\n\nThe gameplay consists of Isaac killing monsters at his basement with his own tears (because he's sad that his mom left him)
column22: dodging enemy bullets
column23: going to item rooms to get items and be more powerful and killing the boss of the floor to get deeper. After certain conditions are met
column24: you get to do a Deal with the Devil
column25: where you trade your health containers (you can get them from HP ups) for usually damage items
column26: with some exceptions. Most of the floors contains a item room and a shop where you can spend money for other resources and items.\n\nIsaac collects pennies
column31: runes and trinkets (they work like temporary items). Pennies can be used to play on slot machines and buy items on the shop
column32: bombs can be used to make pathways or combat
column33: and keys open locked chests and locked doors. Pills
column34: tarot cards and runes stay on a slot until you use them

reviewerDisplayName: Day Man Champion of the Sun
reviewText:
Okay, so my first review for this game was kind of shotty and I re read and then hated myself for writing it. These are more collective thoughts on the game after I've played it a little bit more and went back to the original to look at the diffrences in the games.

Things I liked about this game

Gameplay

Overall, the gameplay was really nice. The controller support was an amazing addition and I found myself using the controler over the keyboard becuase it was much easier to control then using arrow keys. The boss battles were fun espically near the end of the game when you have a ton of items and your heart is beating out of your chest as your hp drops to one heart. Those moments are what drove me to keep playing this game. Items felt like each one had a huge impact on the game to get, nothing seemed small and a lot of them could be complete run breakers so even more so then the previous game knowing what items did was crucial. Rooms in general had such a large vairty of layout that it never really felt the same it was always a new experience. Getting hit anywere always made me cuss under my breath knowing how hard it could be to find health unless you really scavanged the areas which was one of my favorite parts of the harder difficultes.

Graphics

Overall the graphics looked really nice, the little effects that were added to this game helped imerse me into the world more then in the previous game. The 16 Bit style was done really nicley in this game and I could still tell all of the previous eniemes from the past game was. It all seemed new but not new enough to make me forget what game I was playing.

Replay-Ability

THe later levels of this game really shined. If i lost, I kept wanting to go back to it to try and get farther then I had the previous time. Random level design and room design mixed with a large amount of diffrent items that all did something diffrent from the last means that no run is every exactly the same, so it still feels fresh after around the 300th death and restart. Achivements could never be gotten in the a single run and you had to get the right circumstances a lot of the time to even get half of them which isnt a bad thing, it drove me to play it again.


Things I did not like


Gameplay

While there was a lot of diffrent things that could happen in this game as far as characters go there was a sumpreme lack of difference, the only really things that changed were stats none of the characters besdies Azel really changed how you had to play the game. We were told that Samson might be more of a melee character which would have been really cool to see but nothing was relesed on that and he just ended up being the same guy he was in the last game except with a few buffs to blood lust. I found myself playing Azel more of the time becuase it was something diffrent then the same mundane tears that you had to start off with. That actually ties into another big problem I had with this game, starting out. The first three of four levels of the game felt so slow and dragged out to me, your damage was usually very low and it took forever to bring one enemy down. It felt more like a chore to get through then actually playing. This was strengthed after having a really really good run and then seeing issac or whoever you may be playing having these little tears shoot out after experiencing knives going every which way. Other issues that I had involved that were run breakers, as I stated earlier you had to know what each item did but to a first time player seeing the cursed eye it looks really similar to another item. I know the game is supposed to be difficult but let that be in the fighting now having a single item that looks very similar to another trash an entire run.

Graphics

Even though the 16bit style has a bit of a charm to it, I feel it's a  little over played in video games today. It can look very beautiful if done correctly and it in no way dosent in this game but I really enjoyed the original style. I wish it had kept to that except gotten a big overhall in how things looked, even with all the graphical glitches and other varius issues the original game had I liked the art style so much better. It made bosses feel more challenging for me, it made mom feel more threatening. When i saw the pixaleted mom foot drop down I almost laughed a little becuase even though yes it still looked threatining the 16bit style took a large amount of the impact tha game had on me.

Replay-Ability

I'm going to restate a lot that I said in gameplay here but go into more detail. A perfect example of the bordem that I suffered in the first two levels was after about a week or so of not playing the game I decided to boot it back up and give it another shot. I picked issac and started shooting at an enemy, after realizing how slow my shots were and how long it was taking the enemy to die then seeing that happen room after room after room on the first floor I gave up on playing it. A lot of the time I had to froce myself through the first few levels becuase I knew how much I enjoyed the later levels. The only fun I really had constantly going back was with Azel becuase enimes that didnt pose any threat died way quicker then other people. Even though the rooms were randomly generated and you didnt see the same room all the time, after a while of playing that didnt seem to matter to me. The rooms seemed the same, the same colors the same the same things to kill. I really wish there was a varient in all of that, even if the same creatures had a randomly generated apperence but still stayed the same morphies flesh blob that it used to be. It would make everything seem a lot more fresh to me.

Overall
7.5/10

I would still buy it, for the cost it should give you more then enough play time before you start to notice all of the things that I pointed out.

reviewText: If you like a good challenge for both you will, mind and self-esteem, this game is perfect for you. With great music, random runs and tense fights every room, it will scare you more than any next-gen game out there. I have played this game for over 50 hours, and I have not even scratched the surface of this game's full glory. With random seeds spicing up runs so you never get bored, plus the game having unique items that can ether ruin or totally carry or run, will really have you begging to mlgesus for that one extra soul heart for good measure, or good items in your shop/item rooms, or you praying that Bob's Rotten Brain does not spawn in your azazel run. But, in all and all, this game is a great game, perfect for when you are bored or on a long ride/flight.  But , heed this word of advice; A. If you have low range,  NEVER  pick up Bob's Rotten Brain, or you will suffer exploding pain. B. Try not to pick up Soy milk, it is really tricky to use. C. If you hate a run a lot, holding R will restart your run with the same character, but with a different seed. D. Unless you are sure  DO NOT PICK UP DEAD CAT   It takes away all but one red heart container, and gives you 9 lives  E. Satan and Isaac are really hard to defeat, so get into a grove before you fight them.\n\nBy the way, this game plays like Super Meat Boy, so if you don't like that game, this probably is not the game for you.

reviewText:
As a battle hardened veteran of the original, I wanted to throw my opinion in the ring.
Pros:
Amazing new engine (hooray, not flash!)
Fantastic new items and combinations!
New characters (and new versions of old characters)
Fun new challenges

Con:
The soundtrack

Now, the soundtrack is okay- it's around par for a game of this type, but the original soundtrack for TBOI was phenomenal. I listened to it for 1600 hours, not including the amount of time I watched other casters play the game, etc.  Danny's music far exceeds the feel of the music of this game... and after only sixty hours of play I have to listen to other music. Thank goodness for a mute feature... as it doesn't have the feel or fun factor of the original.

Overall? 8/10, but a 10/10 for your money.  You'll get a lot of replay out of this game, and it's a blast to get an amazing run and breeze through, or force a bad run all the way through. Buy it (especially when it goes on sale.)

-Elven

reviewText: At first, I was a little disappointed when I realized that this was pretty much a remastered version of the original. However, just an hour with the game dashed that thought from my mind completely. Although the aesthetic and certain audio changes (especially the original music and the fact that Isaac now sounds his age) leave an uncanny feeling with myself, who played the original for a remarkably long time, I feel the engine change has overall benefitted the game. The environments feel darker, and despite the supposed visual downgrade to the pixellated style of yesteryear, even more genuine. The darkness (although occassionally obscuring darkly colored enemies in later, black-er levels) really ups the tension. The music also fits, although regrettably I must admit it has yet to impress me like Mr. Baranowsky's did in the original. The gameplay feels smoother than it did before, as well as looking smoother thanks to the upgrade to a constant 60 FPS. The amount of content, although I have yet to experience much of it, seems to have vastly improved; almost half of the items and enemies in my first playthrough seemed to be brand new. While I cannot speak for those who have not played the original, I picked up the old controls like a bicycle; while it got a bit quirky when I received what I believe was a new item (a cursed eye?) which gave me the ability to charge shots in order to shoot up to four or five at once, my experience with it so far seems that the familiar controls are as comfortable as before. While I must reserve full judgement until I have had more experience with the game, Rebirth is as engaging an experience as its predecessor, presenting the same elements that made it great and improved it through content and a very beneficial engine upgrade.

reviewText:
Even though this is one of the best roguelikes I've ever played, it seems to be made by a complete idiot. A guy who hates fun and fair challenge.

There is a crazy amount of replayability in this because of the huge amount of upgrades and unlocks. Even with the hours I have, I still find myself experiencing new hilarious or broken combos through the random upgrades. It's a great time seeing what your first upgrade will be, and finding synergies for it.

The presentation is mostly good. The art/environment is pretty good. The fighting is good. The items are fun. The challenges are fun. Resources matter. Almost everything is pretty fun.

But then you see the game is riddled with ♥♥♥♥ only Edmund Mcdumdum would leave in which poison a great game. A quick list would include the piece of crap money spending system, unavoidable damage, unfun bad runs, grinding, hidden information and, stemming from that, items that will kill your run instantly because they are pure crap and you don't know until you take it.

MONEY
While the shop system itself is decent enough and even fun, other ways of spending your currency are TERRIBLE.
Shops - These are actually a pretty good design overall. You know it probably isn't worth wasting a key for a shop if you have under 15 pennies and don't need small heals, and they can really help you succeed on any given run.

Slot machines and skull game - these let you pay 1 penny at a time for a x% chance of a small reward, or nothing at all. While a fine concept, it turns into grinding. Many times you will end up with a huge surplus of coins and near the end of the game, this might be the only way to spend money. In a difficult run you want to do all you can to win, don't you? What this equates to, way too often, is slamming your face against a slot machine or skull game for 5 minutes hoping to get something because you can only donate 1 penny at a time. So choose: either grind for several minutes, or leave and pass up an increased chance of success. THIS COULD BE FIXED BY SIMPLY ALLOWING US TO DONATE MORE AT A TIME. WHAT THE HELL EDMUND. Edmund loves to waste your time instead of letting you play a game. I cannot believe this has not been fixed even since the first game.

Beggars - Another good way of spending pennies that isn't cancerous and grindy. Spending a penny, one at a time, gives a chance of a small resource drop or a full-on upgrade. This is actually acceptable to give only one at a time because the beggar takes them faster than slot machines or skull games do, and you will usually not even need to give 20 pennies before the beggar goes away. This takes like 20 seconds compared to the several minutes of slamming your head against a wall with the slots.
UNAVOIDABLE DAMAGE
The more this game is updated, the more unavoidable damage that keeps finding its way into the game. Sometimes getting hit really, really matters. And it sure matters if your'e going for the no-damage achievements. There is even a character who dies in one hit. Too many times you get damaged because of a stat check or an enemy's design combined with a room's design. Some examples, but not limited to:
Suicide bombers - Very fast movement and enough life to take a couple hits, unless you were lucky with damage upgrades. If you don't have a good speed stat or a good damage stat, you will be hit in a small room. Sorry. Deal with it. Goodbye no-damage run, or goodbye because you were low on hearts already. If the bombers are bunched up a little better when you get into the room, you might be able to run around them. Suicide bomber problems are not too rare.

Creep - Puddles of damage left on the floor by enemies. At certain times, especially in the small-sized boss rooms, you might be left with nowhere to move and be forced to walk onto the stuff or just eat a bullet because you can't move. Congrats - you just got hit. This is pretty rare, at least.

Enemy Brimstone - There is one boss who shoots a beam of damage and makes it spin around the room from its origin...it's a classic gaming convention; memories of Contra 3. The problem with it is that the boss position is random. If he is against a wall then, well...congrats - you just got hit.

Room shape + enemy AI - Some rooms do not give you space to move; there is a single path the size of your character that goes around the room. See any fast enemies or is your damage just too low? Well congrats - you just got hit.
UNFUN BAD RUNS
I know bad runs are an important part of the genre, but it doesn't mean a bad run can't be fun. This game handles the existence of bad runs awfully. In many games, a hard run is hard because it's hard to dodge things, or just that fighting is hard in general and you don't have great items. In this game....it is hard because you will spend 15 seconds on one stupid enemy because you're a weak peice of crap. He's still gonna stand there like a dumbass, or just limp at you like a ♥♥♥♥♥ while you pelt peas at him as you circle the room. Wow, skill. Actually it's just wasting my time. Much of the time, being too weak just makes rooms take insanely long and makes the game boring. Weakness should be introduced in a way that doesn't make the game take literally 10 times as long, such as enemies being able to beat your face in harder; not by forcing me to kite each stupid guy around a room for 30 seconds while I'm yawning.

Bosses are even worse as they might take several minutes when you're a weak peice of crap. A lot of them this doesn't even make harder. It makes them a grind. You will be doing the same stupid predictible dodging pattern on a boss for about 6 years and falling asleep until you lose concentration out of boredom. A challenge is fun, but a 'challenge' that makes me spend disgusting amounts of time walking around a room basically invincible is not fun. Not all bosses are easy like that, but that doesn't make it any more fun dodging the same attack for 3 minutes while throwing ping pong balls.

Hard runs like this also often force you to slam your face against slot machines all day. Ugh....

Introduce a challenge that isn't about wasting time and gross repitition.

GRINDING
Though a recurring element elsewhere, this is mostly about donation machines. You can put pennies into donation machines that are usually just in stores for the benefit of upgrades and bonuses that is persistent through runs. This is fun! But wait...

Having a big money run and ready to spend that juicystack of 99 pennies in the donation machine? Well there is a chance that the machine jams for no reason. Congrats - you just donated like 3 pennies and now can't donate until the next run.

This is especially bad in greed mode where you can't even donate until the end of the game. Not only is it tough to have pennies left by the end of greed mode, the last boss makes you drop pennies when hit. This is all pretty okay. The real problem is that the greed machine, once it's at a pretty good donation rate, has up to 20% chance of jamming. Trying to get 999 pennies in there to unlock the extra character? Well I hope you like beating the whole game for the chance to insert a whole penny :-) thanks for the grind. I like when games are about grinding and luck instead of skill so this is great for me.

Continued in comments.

reviewText:
The Binding of Isaac: Rebirth is a game for patient gamers. I finished every achievement, and had a lot of fun doing so. But it was not always fun. There were times when I raged like a gorilla. It is important not to give up in this game.
So I recommend this to everyone who doesn't give up after 10 minutes of gameplay. First reason is because it takes a good while to get fimiliar with the game. There are lots of items, all of which do something else, and getting to know them takes a long long time. Ofcourse you could look them up on the internet, which I did at times, or you could just use the hints given by the game to figure out what every item does.  Secondly, the game works in runs. You play the same maps every time, in the same order, except randomly generated with seeds. So even though it is always the same, it is never the same. If you think this will bore you quickly, then I would not buy this game.
The enemies are always strong, but you are not always. It depends on your randomly generated seed, what items will drop, and items are what makes you strong. So you need to pray to RNJesus that your seed will have strong items. If you do get them, however, you're gonna have a great time. Items being all different, is also the case with enemies and bosses. None are alike, they are all different in their patterns and attacks. It requires a fair amount of patience to get fimiliar with the game. But in the end it is worth it.
buy this game m9 u'll have a gr9 time i r9 9/9 dont h9

reviewText:

good controls (xbox 360 controller is a must have!)
many many items and mechanics to explore
ability to play Co-Op (local only)
the game gets harder over timeCons:
Can be very frustrating when you loose, especially at the beginning
It's a hard gameTo conclude, people who like to feel their own improvement and to explore the games mechanics, enemies, bosses and items should give this game a try!
